title: Drawing Media, an Interview With Jason Kottke
content:
Hi, Edith here. This is the first in an interview series in which I talk to people about their media diets and habits. Jason seemed like a good person to start with as we figure out the format, although honestly his actual Media Diet series is more thorough. Look for the next installment in a few weeks!

So, have you seen or read anything good recently?
I saw Dune Two on opening weekend. And I went by myself, which I like to do. There are no IMAX screens in Vermont, but thereâ€™s a theater about 45 minutes from me with a screen called the T-Rex. Itâ€™s not quite IMAX, but itâ€™s not bad either.

I wasnâ€™t a crossword puzzle person beforehand â€“ and I kind of hate Scrabble because at a certain level itâ€™s all about strategy and memorization, which is boring to me. I felt similarly about crossword puzzles, but then she and I started doing them, and I was like, â€œOh this is actually pretty fun,â€ and now we do maybe two or three a week.

And I donâ€™t do Wordle, but I do play the Spelling Bee and Connections. And Iâ€™ll do the little mini crosswords on my phone. But a lot of that is just procrastinating about getting out of bed in the morning.

So theyâ€™re mostly morning experiences for you?
Yes. I will go back to Spelling Bee, though, if I didnâ€™t do well in the morning.

Whatâ€™s doing well?
I donâ€™t get Genius every day, but I would like to. But sometimes I just donâ€™t have the patience for the particular puzzle, and Iâ€™m like, Iâ€™m sorry, I donâ€™t want to grind.

You mentioned that you read Middlemarch last year. How did you squeeze that in? Because thatâ€™s a commitment.

I couldnâ€™t get enough books, because I wasnâ€™t reading anything online. I stopped cold turkey, basically. Right now Iâ€™m listening to a good audiobook, though: Blood in the Machine, by Brian Merchant. Itâ€™s about the Luddites.

It was painted as an anti-technology movement in the early 19th century, but the book recontextualizes it as a labor movement. Rich factory owners were introducing new technologies, and people were getting laid off. Workers were angry and would go into the factories to smash machines, but they would only smash the ones that were, like, driving people out of work. The machines that actually helped the laborers do their jobs, those were kept.
